job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Cafe food is awesome, some really genuine and caring people.
cons: If you have a license. STAY AWAY and protect your livelihood. Very unsafe conditions, both for staff and patients. Lots of employee injuries where they blame the employee for the conditions. Patients are constantly harmed, and management refuses to make changes. Vendors are never paid. Everything is "on credit hold." Upper management really doesn't develop anyone and there are never raises. Everyone seems to hate working there and live in constant fear. Just an awful place.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Friendly staff, great insurance, good place to start nursing
cons: They offer 1.5% 401k match but haven’t payed it in over 6 months. Offer tuition reimbursement but stopped paying

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Salt Lake, NM
pros: It could've been worse but it wasn't to bad

job_title: Buyer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Nothing really good. Toxic environment and poor leadership.
cons: The company prides itself on being a family environment. However, it is a facade. Leadership is by far the worst I’ve ever had. There was no teamwork and no support from director. There was no communication and no training provided for my position. There was no learning and self-achievement. I don’t recommend anyone to work at this place. They treat employees badly. Bathroom on basement is always dirty. PTO bank includes sick and vacation time without a generous accrual. no paid maternity leave.

job_title: Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The pay is competitive, the PTO is also good..
cons: They put money ahead of patient care even when it comes to basic supplies and safety. Their staffing is very limited and there are no standards or rules to follow. The house supervisor figures things out for the next shift any way they choose and staffing widely varies by who is working. They have no rules regarding electronic devises and staff have their phones, laptops and other devices with them and use these to the detriment of patient care.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Overall, many of the people at the facility are friendly.  There is a feeling of community within the hospital.
cons: Almost all of the managers/directors lack soft skills.  The reason they have moved into higher positions is because they have stuck around the industry, not because of their actual management skills.  The only time anything is addressed is when a serious problem has occurred or when something is broken.  They are not proactive.

review_title: One of the worst hospitals to work for as an RN in Utah
job_title: Registered Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Their cafeteria offers some of the most delicious hospital food. Thanks to their amazing cooks! 
...although I can’t say if the “cardiac diet” menu for the patients follow a truly heart-healthy or low in fat/sodium diet.

The float position offers a slightly higher hourly wage than regular unit positions...but a couple more dollars is seriously NOT worth losing your RN license (and your sanity).

The med-surg floor nurses, aids and manager (bless their hearts) were the better people to work with compared to the other rotten floor staff.
cons:
First of all, this is a very small community hospital, all of the staff know each other, and if you’re not willing to partake in kissing up to management’s manipulative ways or participate in their ridiculous politics and “click-y” ways, this isn’t the right workplace for you. I would say that the veteran staff here can be quite Discriminatory. I have heard some racially charged comments said by some of the staff especially in the ER and “ICU” towards other people. They are ALWAYS short staffed to the point where they let nurses handle very unsafe patient ratios. I’ve never dealt with such careless managers. They did not care what so ever about their unit nurses. Forget about asking the managers for time off, it won’t happen, because they don’t know how to listen. Some of them shouldn’t even be working as managers. 

I do not recommend any new nurses getting their first nursing job here...unless of course you want to risk losing your license. Their charting system isn’t intuitive...good luck with learning that. I feel so sad for the few good hard working people I’ve met at this hospital and I wish you well. As for the management, they are hopeless.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Coworkers are great. People are friendly with others.
cons: Management let’s it be known there is a real disconnect between “you” and “them.” Have as many opinions/suggestions as you like.. they don’t matter and won’t be taken into account.
